title: Are radio stations only allowed to play singles? - Quora

response.answer_text: It depends on the the kind of station. Even in our internet world where you can select the songs you want to hear and never listen to a radio station, radio is still popular with a lot of people. And in an effort to meet the needs of the listeners, most commercial radio stations have what is called a “format.” This refers to the type of music programming you will hear on that station. For example, top-40 is one type of format; it is often aimed at teens and young adults, and it plays only the biggest hit songs on the pop music charts (based on requests, digital downloads, sales of CDs— which some people do still buy— etc). Originally, back in the early 1950s, stations were like jukeboxes and they only played about forty songs over and over. Today, while top-40 does have a lot of repetition (the term for this is “rotation”— heavy rotation means a song is a huge hit and is played more often than a song that’s not as well known and is in a lighter rotation), there are very few top-40 stations that just play 40 songs. Today’s top-40 format usually has some recent hits, a few up-and-coming songs, and even an occasional oldie in addition to the big current hits. Another format is called album rock. This style of radio plays the biggest and best tracks from the albums of popular artists, as well as new music, recent album tracks, and older tracks. For example: where a top-40 station would just play the hit song from an album, an album rock station would also play some tracks that were not hits but are still great songs. And that’s the answer— a top-40 station generally restricts itself to singles, or to the one song on a new album that is perceived to be a hit. Stations that feature other formats (album rock, jazz, world music, dance music, just to name a few) are not restricted to just the hit single, so they will play a wider variety. Thus, it’s not that a station isn’t allowed to do X; it’s that the station’s listeners expect a certain format, and the station’s deejays tend to follow along with what their audience wants to hear.

Not by law, but many choose to do so. I’ve not listened to radio for many years, but there used to be some “Album Rock” stations that would sometimes play entire albums at a time at least part of the time, and would play ANY cut from ANY album they had by request.

Some countries do have licencing restrictions that prevent broadcast radio stations from playing whole album, so yes. In addition to this many stations run structured music playlists and formats, and these formats often contain rules to prevent music from the same artist being played back to back. I hope that helps.

I am not 100% sure on this. However, I have a friend who runs a radio station, and has told me that he can play entire album tracks if he wanted to. Generally, he chooses not to because not all of his listening audience share the same tastes. So variety is beneficial to keeping listeners tuned in.

No, they can play albums and a very few will do so from time to time. Singles allow a station to craft variety basd on their own choices, testing, etc. But they are not restricted to singles if they choose to play albums.

Nope… They can play whatever they want to. They get a broadcasting licence. That gives them the ‘authority’ to broadcast their content. It does not, however, restrict what songs they can play - or the length of each tune.
Most stations are playing digital versions of whatever songs they play…whether a single or album cut.
